summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from June 2020 between FBI agents and Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs) regarding the investigation of Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss obtaining Maxwell's Amazon records via subpoena, activating a USPS mail cover on her, and analyzing her phone activity, which had become less active.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The primary subject of the investigation. The emails discuss subpoenaing her Amazon records, analyzing her phone activity, and placing a mail cover on her to monitor her communications.

events.title: Subpoena for Maxwell's Amazon Records Requested
events.description: An FBI detective requests Assistant U.S. Attorneys to prepare a subpoena for Ghislaine Maxwell's Amazon records to check for recent activity, address changes, or new phone numbers.

events.title: USPS Mail Cover Activated on Maxwell
events.description: An FBI agent confirms that a U.S. Postal Service (USPS) mail cover on Ghislaine Maxwell is now active, with results expected soon. The cover involves photocopying her mail, which remains USPS property and must be returned.

events.title: Discussion on Obtaining Mail Cover Data Electronically
events.description: An AUSA proposes checking with a postal inspector to see if mail cover data can be obtained electronically to speed up the process, without disclosing case particulars.

keyFacts: In June 2020, investigators were actively subpoenaing Ghislaine Maxwell's Amazon records to track her activity, addresses, and potential new phone numbers.
A U.S. Postal Service (USPS) mail cover was active on Maxwell, meaning her physical mail was being monitored and photocopied as part of the investigation.

Analysis of Maxwell's phone records indicated her phone was 'a lot less active than it was several months ago,' with most calls being incoming or voicemails, prompting investigators to task a CAST team to analyze the records.

The correspondence shows coordination between the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) in the investigation leading up to Maxwell's arrest.
